body:
I am trying to install neo4j enterprise edition 4.4.15 from rpm package. Non interactive install is not working. Have set the below env variable

export NEO4J_ACCEPT_LICENSE_AGREEMENT=yes
sudo rpm --install neo4j-enterprise-4.4.15-1.noarch.rpm

It still asks for license agreement. Have tried with other versions as well still the same. Please help on this.

subject: Graph Academy Spelling Errors
search_snippet: Loving Graph Academy so far; it's a fantastic resource! However, I've noticed quite a few spelling errors throughout the first 3 courses. I've not kept track of them all but the most recent I noticed...
body:
Loving Graph Academy so far; it's a fantastic resource! However, I've noticed quite a few spelling errors throughout the first 3 courses. I've not kept track of them all but the most recent I noticed was "Having this type of instance model will help use to test our use cases.", which I assume should read "us", located at the end of Graph Data Modeling Fundamentals > Purpose of the Model.

I don't mind going back through the courses I've already completed and collating a list of the mistakes I've seen so far and noting down any I see in future too if that would be helpful to the community. ðŸ˜‡

subject: Link Prediction Pipeline for Protein Target Binding
search_snippet: I'm trying to construct a pipeline for link prediction to find novel links between the entity nodes. My objective is to identify the future links between protein and target given positive and negativ...
body:
I'm trying to construct a pipeline for link prediction to find novel links between the entity nodes. My objective is to identify the future links between protein and target given positive and negative links. I referred to the co-author link prediction tutorial, in that they considered all pair of nodes that donâ€™t have a relationship as negative classes. But in my case, I have two csv files, one with the positive classes (i.e, proteins binding to a target) and other with the negative classes (i.e., proteins not binding to a target). I created the network as: (P:protein_id)-[:POSITIVE]-->(T:target_id) and (P:protein_id)-[:NEGATIVE]-->(T:target_id). Is that approach correct for the link prediction?

I also want to include tested_species, scale, unit and value (will use this as a weight property), all of these being string values except the target_measure_value, would that improve the prediction if I add them as properties to the target_id node or should I add them as separate nodes. Can someone guide how to proceed with this, thanks in advance.

protein_id target_id tested_species target_measure_scale target_measure_units target_measure_val target
A0JP26 mus musculus homo sapiens ic50 ug/ml 0.01 POSITIVE
A1L190 hiv inhibition trypanosoma cruzi mc50 um 10 POSITIVE

protein_id target_id tested_species target_measure_scale target_measure_units target_measure_val target
A2RUB6 venom activity homo sapiens ic50 um 1000 NEGATIVE
A4D1B5 signalling activity rattus norvegicus mc50 ug/ml 250 NEGATIVE

body:
Hi everyone,

I'm using Neo4j Bloom to visualize a graph, but whenever I do a query it shows my multi-labeled nodes with the same color, even though in the right panel it actually allows to set different ones, and in Neo4j Browser the coloring works. I already check the color settings using the command ":style" and they are actually different. Any suggestion?

Thanks

subject: Neo.ClientError.Statement.SyntaxError â€“â€“Â expected  'i/I' â€“â€“ Query
search_snippet:
Hi, 
 Please, I am getting an error with a query, an example illustrated below. My objective is to obtain the family_names based on the matches of first_name etc. Where the most suitable match comes ...
body:
Hi,

Please, I am getting an error with a query, an example illustrated below. My objective is to obtain the family_names based on the matches of first_name etc. Where the most suitable match comes on top, and then other matches with common first_name follow in ascending order, as displayed in the table.

However, I am getting a Cypher syntax error. Please, how do you suggest I fix the issue?

Thanks.

MATCH(n:name{first_name:'Jay'})
MATCH(h:hometown{hometown:'New Jersey'})
MATCH(r:race {race:'Black'})
MATCH(f:family_name)
WHERE (f)-[:first_name]->(n)
AND (f)-[:hometown]->(h)
AND (f)-[:race]->(r)
WHERE f.first_name contains 'Jay'
RETURN f
ORDER BY f asc
LIMIT 10;
#Cypher #CSV #Neo4J #SyntaxError

subject: Exact match for string with CONTAINS
search_snippet:
Hi all, i have been stuck on an issue related to cypher matching.  
 So we have multiple nodes which contains a property 'x_matchKey' and we use this x_matchKey property to fetch the result with a CO...
body:
Hi all, i have been stuck on an issue related to cypher matching.

So we have multiple nodes which contains a property 'x_matchKey' and we use this x_matchKey property to fetch the result with a CONTAINS.

the query goes like that that:
MATCH (a:person)->[r:occupies]->(b:position) WHERE b.x_matchKey contains 'cto' return a. This query is intended to fetch the person whose position is cto. Its was working fine from past few years.

Now there's another node which contains 'director' in the x_matchKey property.

So when i run this query now, it returns both persons as 'director' also contains 'cto'.

Also, i can't use '=' operator as x_matchKey contains various terms for a person (Like 'cto, Chief Techniology Officer, EVP, Technical officer'). Basically there are more than two comma separated values for each x_matchKey.

Is there any way that i can search if a property contains only a specific word rather than a substring?

I hope i have explained it well, if not please feel free to reply on this thread.

Thanks in advance for all the future suggestions.

subject: Calculating Quantiles in cypher
search_snippet:
I wanted to calculate quantile values over a list of integers. In python, there is Numpy library which does that as follows: 
 import numpy  list = [4, 6, 1, 3, 10, 5]  q3 = numpy.quantile(list, 0.75...
body:
I wanted to calculate quantile values over a list of integers. In python, there is Numpy library which does that as follows:

import numpy
list = [4, 6, 1, 3, 10, 5]
q3 = numpy.quantile(list, 0.75) #5.75
q2 = numpy.quantile(list, 0.50) #4.5
q1 = numpy.quantile(list, 0.25) #3.25

How would I be able to do this in cypher?

subject: Re: Exact match for string with CONTAINS
search_snippet:
Maybe you should store the descriptions as a list instead of a comma concatenated string. You could then determine if the list contains the exact phrase you want.      
 if that is not an option, you...
body:
Maybe you should store the descriptions as a list instead of a comma concatenated string. You could then determine if the list contains the exact phrase you want.

if that is not an option, you could split the string into a list and determine if the list contains the exact string you want to match.

you could also use a grep search to restrict you results so that it is a whole word from a comma concatenated list.

https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/current/functions/string/#functions-split

subject: Re: Neo.ClientError.Statement.SyntaxError â€“â€“Â expected  'i/I' â€“â€“ Query
search_snippet:
You have two â€˜whereâ€™ clauses. Change the second â€˜whereâ€™ clause to â€˜andâ€™. 
 Also, you canâ€™t order by a node, as you are trying to do with â€˜order by fâ€™ change it to â€˜order by f.first_name ascâ€™ 
 finall...
body:
You have two â€˜whereâ€™ clauses. Change the second â€˜whereâ€™ clause to â€˜andâ€™.

Also, you canâ€™t order by a node, as you are trying to do with â€˜order by fâ€™ change it to â€˜order by f.first_name ascâ€™

finally, you canâ€™t have a pattern as a predicate. You can change them to use â€˜existsâ€™ to convert them to predicates. For example, change â€˜(f)-[:first_name]->(n)â€™ in the â€˜whereâ€™ clause to â€˜exists((f)-[:first_name]->(n))â€™.

question: why do you need to match to the other nodes â€˜raceâ€™ and â€˜hometownâ€™, as it seems you just want to find the last name of everyone whose first name contains â€˜jayâ€™. You will not receive your expected results you list with your query, because all three donâ€™t match the values of race and hometown in your query. You should get your expected results with the following query:

MATCH(f:name)
WHERE f.first_name contains 'Jay'
RETURN f
ORDER BY f asc
LIMIT 10
Just realized one more issue, you limit the â€˜nameâ€™ node to have a first name exactly equal to â€˜Jayâ€™ in the match, so the where clause looking for first names contains â€˜Jayâ€™ will not work.

subject: Re: Adjacency matrix
search_snippet: Just a couple notes. The order of the query operations will cause the 'match(p:part) collect(p)' block to be repeated for each customer node.  Also, its not allowed to introduce a variable in a patte...
body:
Just a couple notes. The order of the query operations will cause the 'match(p:part) collect(p)' block to be repeated for each customer node. Also, its not allowed to introduce a variable in a pattern expression, so returning r.revenue isn't allowed. I refactored your query to resolve these two issues. 

match(c:customer)
with collect(c) as customers
match(p:part)
with customers, collect(p) as parts
unwind customers as customer
unwind parts as part
optional match (customer)-[r:customer_to_part]->(part)
return customer.id as cust_id, part.id as part_id,
case
    when r is not null then r.revenue
    else 0
end as value

subject: Re: Return a COUNT VALUE from a SUB-QUERY and check if a condtion is satisfied
search_snippet:
Hello @glilienfield, 
 thanks for your reply, but that is not what I wanted. I wanted to be flexible in the way I do the nesting with count. Since CALL {}-subquery can not be placed inside of a CALL ...
body:
Hello @glilienfield,

thanks for your reply, but that is not what I wanted. I wanted to be flexible in the way I do the nesting with count. Since CALL {}-subquery can not be placed inside of a CALL {}-subquery, I assumed it should work with EXISTS{}-SUBQUERY. However, in EXISTS{}-SUBQUERY, no WITH-Clause can be called to define what shall be counted. CALL-IN-A-CALL still does not work see it at:

https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/5/clauses/call-subquery/
https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/4.4/clauses/call-subquery/

That is just regarding Cypher 4.4. I also asked my question in the discord developer chat, and just a few weeks later, they created Cypher 5.X functionality for subquery with Count. See: https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-cheat-sheet/5/

From now on Cypher has the Subcall-procedure for COUNT.

MATCH (p:Regesta)
WHERE COUNT { (p)--(d:other) } > 1
RETURN p.name AS name

In this example the path will be counted and inside of the COUNT{} x further COUNTS{} can be placed.

subject: Re: Calculating Quantiles in cypher
search_snippet:
Hi,   
  in my case, the list is the different values of annot.value returned by a query. annot is a node that has a property named 'value' with a float type.   
 match (:Search{searchId:"4e69-9ebd-b...
body:
Hi,

in my case, the list is the different values of annot.value returned by a query. annot is a node that has a property named 'value' with a float type. 

match (:Search{searchId:"4e69-9ebd-b02e1b0c0d49"})-[:FIRST]->(:SearchSession)-[:ANNOTATION]->(annot:FigureAnnotation)
RETURN apoc.agg.percentiles(annot.value, [0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0]) AS percentiles;

perhaps you can make a similar query?

subject: Re: Issue with relationship property creation in Spark submit job: Please provide a valid WRITE quer
search_snippet:
Hello @Cobra , 
 Thanks for your reply, I tried your solution and it works. But when I want to set multiple items it doesn't. 
 MATCH (s:Destination {EXPERIENCE: event.CODE}) 
MATCH (t:Experience {ID...
body:
Hello @Cobra ,

Thanks for your reply, I tried your solution and it works. But when I want to set multiple items it doesn't.

MATCH (s:Destination {EXPERIENCE: event.CODE}) 
MATCH (t:Experience {ID: event.ID}) 
MERGE (s)-[r:HAS_EXPERIENCE]->(t) 
SET r.weight = event.WEIGHT, r.height = event.HEIGHT

This doesn't work and this also doesn't work:

SET r += {weight: event.WEIGHT, height: event.HEIGHT }

Any idea why? Does it only support a single property to set?

subject: Re: Calculating Quantiles in cypher
search_snippet:
Thanks, I did it this way and it worked ... 
   
  WITH [4, 6, 1, 3, 10, 5] as list
UNWIND list as l
RETURN apoc.agg.percentiles(l, [0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0]) AS percentiles
body:
Thanks, I did it this way and it worked ...

WITH [4, 6, 1, 3, 10, 5] as list
UNWIND list as l
RETURN apoc.agg.percentiles(l, [0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0]) AS percentiles

subject: Re: Find similarity of given node with entire graph
search_snippet: There looks to be a filtered version of KNN, where you can specify the source and/or target nodes. The filter can be for specific nodes or labels. With this, you should be able to specify your single...
body:
There looks to be a filtered version of KNN, where you can specify the source and/or target nodes. The filter can be for specific nodes or labels. With this, you should be able to specify your single node in the filtered source nodes, so it finds the the K nearest neighbors for your single node.

it looks to be in alpha state

https://neo4j.com/docs/graph-data-science/current/algorithms/alpha/filtered-knn/
